importance: This paper is crucial because **it addresses the scalability challenge in diverse ensemble training**, a critical issue in large-scale machine learning applications.  Its novel framework, SED, enables the creation of diverse ensembles even without a separate OOD dataset, thereby significantly reducing the cost and effort associated with data preparation. The proposed method also improves OOD generalization and detection performance. This work opens up new avenues for research in robust model training and adaptation to real-world scenarios, which often lack the ideal separation between in-distribution and out-of-distribution data.
summary: Scalable Ensemble Diversification (SED) revolutionizes diverse ensemble training by dynamically identifying out-of-distribution samples within a single large-scale dataset, boosting OOD generalization and detection.
takeaways: SED dynamically identifies and leverages OOD samples from the training data without requiring separate OOD datasets, improving scalability.
SED improves OOD generalization and detection accuracy across multiple benchmarks using various ensemble methods.
Predictive Diversity Score (PDS), a novel uncertainty measure based on prediction diversity, enhances OOD detection performance.
tldr:
Training diverse neural network ensembles enhances out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization and detection, but existing methods require well-separated ID and OOD datasets, which is often unrealistic for large-scale applications. This limitation hinders the practical applicability of diverse ensemble training in real-world scenarios. 
The proposed Scalable Ensemble Diversification (SED) framework tackles this limitation by dynamically selecting OOD samples from the ID training data, thereby removing the need for a separate OOD dataset.  SED uses a novel uncertainty score estimator based on ensemble diversity (Predictive Diversity Score). Results show significant improvements in OOD generalization and detection across several benchmarks, highlighting SED's effectiveness in large-scale datasets and its contribution to more robust and reliable machine learning models.
